resources.string: Logo for the Hyde Park Gym

Press this button to begin or continue working out. 

• This takes you to the Grid, where all your exercises are listed and the details of your workouts can be found. Most of the time you will start at the Grid, that's why it's the top button! 

Get ready to sweat!
Tap on this button to change the settings for this program. \n\nDon\'t worry, they are pretty straight-forward.
This button takes you to a screen where you may export your workout to some common formats. \n\n(Right now, this part is still a work-in-progress, so it doesn\'t do much.)
Seeing your progress is a great part of getting in shape. Press this button to look at all sorts of graphs of how your workouts and your body is changing over time.
Press this button to quit the application. Surprised\? Didn\'t think so.

Welcome to the Hyde Park Gym Workout Tool. This app records your workouts and tracks your progress. 

• Note that this app is descriptive, not proscriptive. That is, it doesn't tell you what you SHOULD do, it just keeps track of what you did. Come on, you're smart enough to know what sort of workout you want (or at least to find the information for yourself). 

• For general help about what a screen does, tap on the Hyde Park Gym logo at the top right of the screen. 

• For help on specific functions, long-tap (press and hold for a second or two) any button or widget, and a help message will pop up describing that function. 

• The first time you use this app, a few popular exercises are listed already listed. You will have to add your favorite exercises to the list. But the program will remember your exercises, so the next time you workout, you can simply select that exercise from the list. 

• Choose an exercise and record what you completed for that set. Do it again for each set. The data you enter is added to a database which can be viewed to track your progress. 

• You can change your name from the boring 'default user' and add other users for this app by tapping on the name. It's a pretty nifty screen—other cool bookkeeping stuff can be done there, check it out. 

• This app was created by Scott Morgan Biggs in his spare time. The good people at Hyde Park Gym in Austin, Texas provided invaluable help and assistance. They also trusted me with their good name, but are in no way responsible for any damage, frustration, or insults that may (or may not) crop up while using this app. So you should send your hate messages to me through the Google Play site. I promise to do my best to address the issues (which may not be much—I am very far from a programming god, sorry). 

Anyway, I did lots of this stuff in the middle of the night, so you might be amused or offended by some of these help messages. So it goes. But in any event, I hope this app is as useful to you as it has been to me. And THANKS to Brook and all the good people at HPG! 

Have a good workout!

Hyde Park Gym (4125 Guadalupe St., Austin, TX, 78751, http://hydeparkgym.com/ ) is owned and run by Brook Jones. This tool was created with the help of him and many of the other fine folks at Hyde Park Gym\u2014just look for place with the big arm sticking out! Programmed by Scott M. Biggs.

This takes you to a screen to manage your all the different users. You can add more users to the app, change the active user, clear the user\'s data, and more! \n\n\u2022Details of the user\'s data, like their exercises and workout sets are changed from the main grid (tap the \'workout\' button).
Are you sure you want to go back to the main workout screen\? This will abandon all entries you\'ve made here.

Create a new exercise on this screen. 

name: Give this exercise a good name (something to easily distinguish it from other exercises). 

exercise type: Exercises generally fall into two different types: anaerobic and aerobic. 

 • Anaerobic are strength building exercises like bench presses and squats. 

 • Aerobic exercises build endurance and cardiovascular health (jogging, jump rope, and swimming are examples). 

 – You need to tell this program what type of exercise this is because it does keep track, and we don't want to confuse how your muscles are worked! 

muscle group: Which group of muscles you are using with this exercise? You don't have to be too specific; a rough guesstimate is good enough. 

aspects: Select the checkbox to left for each measurement you want to record for this exercise. Uncheck to disable this measurement. 

 • Touch the drop-down to the right to select the unit of measurement. If you want to create your own unit, select customize and fill in the following form. 

significant: For each exercise, there is usually one measurement that is the most important. Select the radio button on the right side next to the measurement that is the most important part of this particular exercise. 

other: This section allows you to customize an exercise. You can name both the measurement AND the unit. This is for those exercises that I just could not think of. 

• And like always, you can long-touch (touch and hold for two seconds) any widget and get specific help for that item. 

Now for an example: 

A good friend is a competitive synchronized swimmer, and her team has some unusual exercises. 

• One of the exercises is called 'Smiling', so she enters that for the name. 

• Repetitions are counted, so she checks reps. 

• There are no levels to this exercise, so she leaves this unchecked (levels are generally used with exercise machines like Stair Steppers or rowers). 

• Calories? Yes, she is quite concerned about calories, but there is no simple way to measure them. So calories is left blank. 

• Smiling is not weighted (imagine if it were!), so that remains unchecked. 

• However there is a distance, so she checks distanced and taps on the drop-down button and selects millimeters. 

• Time is measured for this exercise, so she checks timed. They do this exercise to music, counting beats. But beats are not in the time list, so she chooses custom from the drop-down list and types 'beats' in the editbox. 

• But there is one more aspect to the Smiling workout that the program has not provided for: glow. So my friend checks other and types 'glow' in the textbox next to it. 

The unit for glowing while smiling is called 'happies', so she types this in the lower box. 

• Lastly, she must decide which of these is the most significant part of the smiling exercise. While glowing is very important, this is an exercise, and she most wants to keep track of the repetitions. So she selects the right-most radio button in the reps row. 

• Like most other programs, she hits ok to save the changes, or cancel to, ah, uh, cancel (sigh). 

• Remember, if you later decide to change this exercise, you can edit it by long-pressing the name in the main grid. 

Yeah, that's a long explanation. But you deserve to really understand what you're doing. Right\? 

Have a great workout!

Are you sure you want to cancel\? 

It looks like you are about to cancel, even though you've done a little work on this new exercise. 

(You can turn this warning off in the preferences.)
Type in the name of this exercise here.

Exercises work your body in different ways. Aerobic workouts are for endurance. Anaerobic workouts increase strength. Some exercises do both, and others just can\'t be categorized. Do your best to pick the most appropriate type for this workout.
Tell this program which muscle group this exercise targets. Information here will help the program keep track of what muscles you are exercising and will give more accurate progress charts.
Please select at least one measurement.
Select in the unit of measurement you want to work with. \n\nIf you do not see what you need, feel free to select \'custom\' to create the unit you want to use.

Select this checkbox ON (checked) if this exercise has multiple repetitions that you want to count. Push-ups will use this. Jogging probably will not (unless you obsessively count your steps!). If this is selected, the program will ask you how many time (reps) you performed this exercise.

Turn this checkbox ON (checked) if this workout uses weighted equipment. In other words, how much mass are you moving\? Otherwise this program won\'t bother asking you to enter a weight on this exercise.
Type in the measurement unit you\'re working on. Some examples\u003a pounds, kilograms, ounces, tons, stones, picograms, etc.

Turn this checkbox ON (checked) if this workout measures distance. Obviously you won\'t use this one for bench presses. But many aerobic exercises (like swimming) measure distances. If this is not checked the program won\'t bother asking you to enter any distances for this exercise.
How far are you going\? But we need to know the unit. Any unit will do, like feet, kilometers, inches, milimeters, yards, parsecs, etc.

Turn this checkbox ON (checked) if this workout measures time in any way (like how long the exercise takes, or even a race). Otherwise this program won\'t bother asking you to enter a time with this exercise.
What time unit do you measure this exercise with\? Type it in here. Try seconds, minutes, hours, days, centuries, or whatever fits this exercise.

Turn this checkbox ON (checked) if this workout uses some sort of level. \n\nFor example, a stair climber may have a speed setting; you can use Levels to keep track of this speed. Otherwise this program won\'t bother asking you to enter any levels.

Turn this checkbox ON (checked) if you want to count calories for this exercise! \n\nWhile this program does not calculate calories for you, many exercise machines do. You can enter that information here and this app will keep track of it. Cool, right? Yeah yeah, I know\u2014it\'s just a program.
Please fill out both text boxes for \'Other\'.

In the likely case that I forgot some sort of exercise measurement, checking this line should take care the problem. Of course, if you are satisfied with the regular measurements, you can ignore this section and leave it unchecked. 

The name of the measurement and the unit are also needed. Later, when you perform this exercise, the app will use this name you typed and ask for the number of units you did for that set. 

For example, when working out with tiddly-winks, I need to keep track of progessively larger sizes of my winks. So I'll input 'size' in the first text box and 'winkers' in second, which represents the unit (we T-winkers measure the size of our winks that way). 

So when I do my tiddly-winks set I will input a number representing the progessively larger sizes. That way this program can properly track my tiddly-wink size progress. Sweet.
Type in this box the measurement that you will do for this new exercise. For my tiddly-winks workout, I put \'winks\' in this box.

There is always one part of a workout that is more important than the others. \n\nTouch the radio button to the right of that measurement to tell the program which part you think is the most important. For example, squats are all about the weight. So make sure the weighted line has its radio button turned on. For jogging, the distanced line is probably what you are most interested in.
When you\'re satisfied with all the details of this exercise, press this button (\'done\'), and this will be added to your list of exercies.
If you decide to not add this exercise, hit the cancel button. The program will forget this entire entry.
Tap on this button when you are satisfied and done adding this new exercise. Duh.

Yeah, this screen seems complicated, but it's really not. 

What you see: 
  Before you is a spreadsheet of all your exercises and the workout sets you recorded for those exercises. 

• Each row is an exercise. The first item in the row is the name of the exercise (in orange). 

• The columns are the days you worked out. The top of the column lists the specific date. 

• Each cell tells you how many sets of an exercise you did on that particular date. 

What to do: 
• To record a new set for an exercise, just tap on the exercise name. 

• Pressing and holding an exercise name allows you to edit or delete that entry. 

• To see details of an exercise set, tap directly on its number. 

• If there's just one set for that day (you see the number 1 in the cell), you can edit it immediately by long-pressing that cell. 

• Hit the add button to create a new exercise. 

• The change order button will let you rearrange the order that the exercises are displayed. 

Whew, that was good; time for a shower!
This button takes you to a new screen where you can add a new exercise. It\'s pretty easy; try it!
All your exercises appear in the order you entered them. This ain\'t always the way you like it. Tap this button to go to a screen to modify the order to make it juuuust right.
Scroll through the exercise list here and tap on an exercise to start doing a set. To do more than one set of an exercise, just tap on it again.
Are you sure you want to edit the exercise\u003a

(Hoo boy, get ready for a long one!) 

This screen gives you the ability to modify or delete an exercise. But I gotta start with a caveat: 

WARNING:
 	Changing an exercise may have odd results on workout sets that have already been entered. 

I'll do my best to try to retain data, but some things just won't work (like changing the unit—there is no way I can convert from the old unit to the new one without forcing you to enter some sort of formula, which is the sort of thing you're avoiding by using a computer, right\?). 

Consequently, the sets you did before the change may be a little messed up. Of course you can edit those sets to fix the weirdness if you like. end Warning 

name:  The textbox near the top allows you to change the name. –Ha, that was easy! 

exercise type:  Exercises generally fall into two different types, anaerobic and aerobic. 
 • Anaerobic are strength building exercises like bench presses and squats. 
 • Aerobic exercises build endurance and cardiovascular health (jogging, jump rope, and swimming are examples). 
 — You need to tell this program what type of exercise this is because it does keep track of these things, and we don't want to confuse how your muscles are worked! 

muscle group:  This program wants to know which group of muscles you are using with this exercise. You don't have to be too specific; a rough guesstimate is good enough. 

aspects:  Select the checkbox on the left for each measurement (aspect) you want to record for this exercise. Uncheck to disable this measurement. 

unit:  If applicable, touch the drop-down to the right of the checkbox to select the unit of measurement. If you want to create your own unit, select customize at the bottom of the list. 

significant:  For each exercise, there is usually one measurement that is the most important, which I call the significant aspect. Select the radio button on the right side next to the measurement that is the most important part of this particular exercise. You can skip entries, but not the significant entry. 

other:  This section allows you to completely customize. You can name both the measurement AND the unit. This is a catch-all to allow plenty of customization. 

And like always, you can long-touch (touch and hold for two seconds) any widget and get specific help for that item. 

Now for an example: 

My buddy is a tiddly-winks champion and trains with a very specific exercise called winking. 

• So he types 'winking' for the name. 

• Winking doesn't quite fit into either the standard exercise types, so he chooses misc. 

• This exercise uses fingers and lots of kneeling, so for the muscle group he selects all. 

• He always count repetitions, so he checks reps. 

• There are no levels to this exercise, so he leaves this unchecked (levels are generally used with exercise machines like Stair Steppers or rowers). 

• Counting calories\? for tiddly-winks\? You gotta be kidding! 

• Winks do have a weight, so he checks weighted. He then presses on the drop-down nextdoor and select grains, the unit of weight for a wink. 

• When winking, they do go a distance, but that is not important (accuracy is), so he leaves this unchecked. 

• Time is not an issue in this sport, so that also remains unchecked. 

• But there is one more aspect to the tiddly-winks workout that the program has not provided for: accuracy. So my friend checks other and types 'accuracy' for the name. 

• The unit for accuracy while winking is 'tiddles', so he types this in too. 

• Almost done—he must decide which of these is the most significant part of the winking exercise. While accuracy is important, this is an exercise, and he wants to keep track of the repetitions. So he selects the right-most radio button in the reps row. 

• Finally he hits execute changes to save this exercise. If he decided he didn't want this exercise after all he would tap cancel. 

That's it. Sorry for the long explanation, but I think it's better to bore you to tears rather than letting you languish in confusion. 

Have a great workout!
Type in the name of this exercise here.
If you decide to not edit this exercise, hit the \'cancel\' button. The program will forget this whole sordid episode.

I think you have made some changes to this exercise. 

Are you sure you want to cancel these changes\? 

(You can turn this warning off in the preferences.)
Tap on this button when you are satisfied and done editing this exercise. Yep, that\'ll do it.
Hitting this button resets all the fields to their original values.

Yep, this button does exactly what you think it does: 
It completely removes this particular exercise from the app. 

Also note that any earlier workout sets that you recorded with this exercise will be deleted, too. So think a bit before hitting this button. 

And since this IS kind of a big deal, a confirmation dialog will pop up. It's the least I could do.

Hey you! Pay attention! 

You are about to COMPLETELY REMOVE the "%s" exercise from this program. That means that all data using this exercise will be LOST. 

If you are thinking, "Of course, that is exactly what I want," then press 'yes'. 

Otherwise, I think you will want to tap 'no' or hit the 'back' button. 

(Sorry about the caps, but this IS potentially disastrous!)
Please enter a name for this exercise!
Please check a measurement for this exercise!
Please select a radio button to indicate most important.
Hey, I need a weight unit!
Uh, what about a measurement of distance\?
You forgot to tell me what unit of time (seconds, minutes, hours, etc.)

This page allows you to customize the weight unit for this exercise. I don't know how strong you are or what exercises you're doing, so I can't always predict the units of measurement you may need. This is where you tell me what you're lifting. 

For example, let's say that I'm aspiring to be an Olympic rocket skater (just use your imagination). And I need to be able to lift my feet while wearing my skates a certain number of rocket skate units. And those units are named after the first rocket skater, Timothy Grosserbaumbergotten von Schloffenman Rodriguez di Gamba. 

Just type it in. The program will remember. And of course, you can always come back and change things to TGvSRdG. I won't tell.

This is a widget to hold text. The text to put in should be some sort of weight measurement…. I know, something related to your workout! Yeah, that\'s it\u003a some sort of weight measurement for THIS exercise that you\'re working on right now! \n\nHere\'s a gold star!
What unit of weight for this exercise\?

This page allows you to customize the distance unit for this exercise. I don't dare guess what distance would be reasonable for this exercise, so you will have to tell me how far you're going or moving. 

Let's use the rocket skater example again. These people go really far, but to get better ratings, the television producers decided to avoid the nerdy astronomer units and adopt the more amusing unit of flatumeters. 

So just type in flatumeters. The program will remember. You can even come back later and type in much ruder units. The program won't even flinch.
This is a widget to hold the text of some sort of distance measurement. I wasn\'t omniscient enough to predict how you want to measure the distance for this exercise. Sorry.
What unit of distance for this exercise\?

Time is always slipping… :) and this page allows you to get a litte better grip on it by using whatever time unit you want for this exercise. 

Back to the rocket skater: For the sprints, the time units are very tiny. Oh yeah, these things are FAST for short distances. So we like to use microseconds. 

But, uh, … I didn't put microseconds in my list! No sweat (hehe), type it in and we're back in business.
This is a text area to type in your favorite unit of time for this exercise. \n\nSigh, not very funny this time.
What unit of time for this exercise\?

Okay, this is a little esoteric, but if you hang on with me, I think we can get this figured out. 

In case you come up with an exercise that has some sort of measurement that is NOT a repetition, level, calorie, weight, distance, or some sort of elapsed time, you can fill this out to fulfill this need. 

As an avid rocket skater, I need to measure the volume of rocket fuel that I ingest because, as you well know, the more fuel you drink the faster you go. So for this particular exercise, I simply force myself to drink as much as I can (tasty!). 

However, you can see that volume is not a measurement that I have listed. Wouldn't it be nice to record and keep track of how much (volume) I'm forcing down my throat\? 

This space is where you name that measurement. I am going to type in "volume" for this entry, which is the name of the measurement. The actual unit will go in the next textbox. 

Yeah, that's as clear as mud. Sorry, I'm doing my best; I'm a programmer, not a writer.

Continuing from the help on the previous textbox ("other Name"), we still need to record the unit of volume for this exercise. 

Yes, we rocket skaters are an odd group, and when we drink we REALLY drink. Since rocket fuel is measured in liters, that would be a good way to measure our drinking. 

But since we feed our head with this foamy redish brown fuel, rocket skaters prefer the word 'redhead' over liters. 

So I would simply type "redheads" in this textbox. 

And every time I do this exercise, it will ask me, "How many redheads did you do in this set\?" And I will grin quietly.
Tap the arrows to move a row up or down.

This screen lets you change the order of the exercises. 

It's pretty simple: just click the up or down arrows next to the exercise you want to move. Try it, you'll like it! 

And as usual, you can cancel if you don't like your changes.

I think you have made some changes to the row order here. 

Are you sure you want to cancel these changes\? 

(You can turn this warning off in the preferences.)
You entered a %s set. Good job!
You entered a %s set. Keep it up!
You entered a %s set. Getting stronger every day!
You entered a %s set. Go for it!
You entered a %s set. Time to move up!
You entered a %s set. Getting easy!
You entered a %s set. You can do better!
You entered a %s set. Aw, that was too easy!
You entered a %s set. You\'ll get it!
You entered a %s set. Trying a little to hard?
You entered a %s set. That\'s the spirit, but try a little easier next time.
You entered a %s set. Careful, don\'t hurt yourself!
You entered a %s set. Do you need to see a doctor?
You entered a %s set. Sorry, I bet that hurt.
You entered a %s set. Oooh, that looked painful!

You're now working hard, executing a rigorous set of an arduous exercise. Tell us about it, that's what this program's for, right\?


• The entries from the last time you did the set are automatically filled in. You can change them or press the clear button and start fresh. (Your stress condition is ALWAYS set to 'just right', the first button. The notes from your previous set are just a hint—it will disappear when you save or start writing something else.)


• Input the numbers and any comments and don't forget to press enter set! That's how this program knows to enter this information into the database, duh.


• Select a radio button that indicates how hard this set has been for you (I call it the stress condition). The first choice means that this exercise set was just right—you had to push to complete it.


If the workout was too easy or you're ready to up the amps, select the next radio button, an image of someone lifting a weight that is too light.


If this set was so hard that you could not finish, tap on the third button (too heavy).


I hope your exercises never come to this, but if something odd or bad does happen (accident, injury, etc), press the last button, ouch! At least you can record exactly what you were doing and when it happened.


• The notes section is there for whatever pops up, usually relevant to the set you just did. Of course you're welcome to write that great novel you've been thinking of while catching your breath between sets.


• If you're like me and have big bulky fingers, you can change the width of the number wheel thingies by hitting the menu button. But if your phone is small, this may put a nasty cramp in how this screen lays out. Your call.


If you do not like those number wheel things at all, you can turn them off at the preferences from the welcome screen. (Of course, if you don't see anything they're probably already turned off.) 

• Lastly, if you leaving an item blank is ok as long as it's not the signficant aspect of this exercise, which MUST be entered. Otherwise, blanks just count as a goose-egg (0). 

Enough already, let's get back to working out!
Are you sure you want to go back to the main workout screen\? This will abandon all entries you\'ve made here.
Enter the weight that you\'re using on this set. Please note that if you change weights, you are really starting a new set.
Reps are short for \'repetitions.\' Tell the program how many times you did this exercise. I can\'t believe I have to explain this.
Just enter the time you spent on this exercise set. Use the units provided. You can change the time units by long-pressing this exercise in the main grid.
Enter the level that you used for this set. Levels are usually some sort of setting on a machine. For example, my recumbent bicycle exerciser has settings ranging from 0 to 300.

How many calories did you burn this set\? 

Useless and confusing information:
 	In the science world, a calorie is the amount of heat necessary to raise one gram of water one degree Celcius. 

This isn't very much, compared to the massive amount of heat that food can produce . So in the world of food and exercise, people have used the same word differently (sometimes called a 'dietary calorie' or 'kilocalorie'): one thousand times more heat! That's enough to raise a kilogram of water one degree Celsius. 

Imagine if we were using the small scientific calorie: "Hey, George! You're gonna have to jog a long time to take off the 300,000 calories from that candy bar!"
Enter the distance that you covered with this set. Ask a friend for a ruler if necessary.
While doing your %1$s exercise, enter the number of %2$s here. Hope that sentence makes sense.
If you have any comments or notes for this set, record it here. It\'s also great place to jot down phone numbers\u2014what other app thinks this far ahead\?.
You\'ve started filling in the details for this set. Are you sure you want to cancel\? \n\n(You can turn this warning off in the preferences.)

Tap this button to forget about this set and go back to the main exercise grid.
\n\nSurprised\? I didn\'t think so.

Clicking on this button tells the app that you are done entering data for this set.


This adds the details of this exercise set to that great big database you are making with all these workouts.


Whew, wipe off that sweat and take 30 sec to catch your breath. YEAH!

I think you may have forgotten to fill out these fields:
 %s 
 This is not really a problem, but now is your a chance to go back and fill them in. 

Shall I go ahead and save, leaving some blanks\?

Looks like you forgot to fill in the %1$s field. 

This is not really a problem, but now is your chance to go back and fill it in. 

Shall I go ahead and save, leaving a blank\?

You left the %1$s field blank! \n\nBlank fields are generally not a problem. But since you marked \'%2$s\' as the significant aspect of the %3$s exercise, I have to insist that you put something there. Please\?
You clicked on \'enter set\', but didn\'t do anything! \n\nSorry, but you gotta give me at least one number to enter.
It looks like you didn\'t make any changes. Are you sure that you want to enter this set\? \n\n(You can turn this warning off in the preferences.)
This button is pretty straight-forward; it simply clears all the entries in this workout set.

These four radio buttons are provided to give an indication of how stressful this particular workout set is to accomplish.


The green check, ✔, indicates that this set was nice and hard, but not too hard. Hopefully, most of your workouts will be just right, so this is the default.


The blue feather button means that this set was too easy, and you are ready to increase the difficulty for your next set.


The opposite of too easy is too hard (duh!). I drew some wobbly arms and legs to represent a workout set that was too hard, preventing you from finishing the set. Seriously consider making your next set easier.


Red lines mean bad, very bad. Sometimes we are too zealous with our workouts and get hurt. You may also want to make a note about how and why this happened so you don't repeat this problem again.

Like the exercise that you see\? Want to do it again\? Well, my friend, this button is for you! \n\nPress the \"do another\" button to…yes, you guessed it, do another set of this exercise! Weeeee, isn\'t working out fun\?

Really\? You\'re tired of looking at this information and want do go back to the previous screen\? REALLY\? \n\nI don\'t blame you a bit. You probably have more important things to do than look at my carefully crafted user interface. Go ahead\u2014you won\'t hurt my feelings. Sigh.
Here are the %1$s %2$s sets that you did on %3$s\u003a
Here is the %1$s set you did on %2$s\u003a

Want to see all the details of all your workout sets for this exercise? You've come to the right place! 

• All your workout sets are listed on this screen. Scroll through to see 'em all. 

• Want to reverse the order? No problem. By using the menu all your data can be displayed oldest first (chronological order) or most-recent-first (default). 

• Long click on an exercise set to edit (or even delete) that set. This way you can go back and fix mistakes or even erase bad memories. After all, we're only human.

I think you have made some changes to this exercise set. 

Are you sure you want to cancel these changes\? 

(You can turn this warning off in the preferences.)

This screen allows you to modify or delete an existing exercise set. 

• Tap on the data that you want to change. A dialog will pop up where you can enter a new value. 

• Press the delete set button to remove the whole set. Beware, because you can't get it back (other than entering it in again). 

• As usual, if you change your mind, you can hit the back or the cancel buttons.
This button permanently deletes the data of this one exercise set. You can\'t get it back, but it is pretty easy to re-enter it if you like.
Change your mind? No sweat ;) \n\nJust tap on the cancel button to go back as if nothing had ever happened.
Tap on this button when you are done editing this set. Your changes will be saved for posterity.
You are about to delete a set of the %1$s exercise. There is no going back (other than re-entering it). \n\nAre you sure you want to delete the %2$s set performed on %3$s at %4$s\?
Change the date of this set. Should be pretty easy as this is the default date widget for your device.
This is the time that you finished the set. The elapsed time is entered elsewhere (if applicable).
How many times did you go for this set? Enter your repetitions with this fine and dandy pop-up.
Whether it\'s kilograms, pounds, grains, or tons, you can change the weight of this set here.
What level did you do this set? There\'s probably a setting somewhere that\'ll tell you.
Oh yeah, here\'s a biggie. How many calories did you burn for this set? Doesn\'t matter to me which calorie you use, as long as it\'s consistent.
How far did you go? Answer this question, Grasshoppa, and you will know how to modify this set.

This records the time that elapsed while you did this set. For you and me, just answer the question: How long did this set take to complete? 

For the other time (when you completed the set), look at the 'time' section above. 

Oh yeah, instead of bothering with all those years, minutes, seconds, or whatever, just use the unit it tells you and subdivide into decimal places. So if you're unit is minutes, and you worked on this set for two minutes and thirty seconds, enter 2.5 for your time.
Just enter the number you want. Please.
How stressful was this set? See the help on the next screen for more details.
This allows you to add or change your notes for this set. You can write anything. Anything.

Type in a number here. Like every calculator you've ever used, 'C' clears the entry. 


Gee, why do I even bother\? 'Cause I'm anal, that's why. 

I… must… cross… the… T's… dot… the… I's… and… … … 

 …breathe! Whew.

It looks like you made some changes to this number. 

Are you sure you want to cancel these changes\? 

(You can turn this warning off in the preferences.)
Type in a note for this set\u003a
Type in the new note. Here\'s the old one to compare with\u003a
Yep. You type right here. Yesiree, that\'ll do it. Anything you like. Type it. However your phone or device does it. Do it here. \n\nThat\'s a good boy (or girl or whatever).

It looks like you made some changes to your note. 

Are you sure you want to cancel these changes\? 

(You can turn this warning off in the preferences.)
Select the stress level for this workout set.

Select the stress level of this exercise set. 

 	just right is the selection for your normal workout. You pushed to finish, but did not strain.
 	too easy means just that; this is a note to make it harder next time.
 	too hard indicates that you either could not finish or had to strain dangerously (and unproductively) to finish this set.
 	injury is bad! An injury or something very unusual occurred. Sorry. 

Your stress condition is something I use to know when it's time to up the weight or increase the difficulty in my own workouts. If you don't like this option, then just don't do it. See if I care.

Just like you've seen in so many other apps, here's the preferences screen. But unlike those others, here is a detailed run-down of what each thing does. 

• Nag: Warning pop-ups messages that remind you about important details of an action are called nags. For this app, I will nag you about deleting information every time. But some stuff isn't that important. So you have the option of turning those minor nags off. 

•Sound: Yes, just what you think. Turn sounds on or off. 

•Enable Screen Saver: To save batteries, I generally have my phone's screen saver kick in pretty quickly. But that's distracting and annoying while working out, so I disable the screensaver when this app is running. You can disable my screen saver's disabler :) 

•Number Wheels: When adding information to an exercise set, I added some wheels (or dials if you prefer) as a fun user interface. If you don't think they're fun, simply disable them; doing so can greatly increase the room for small phones. 

•Fat Wheels: If you do have wheels, the gentlemen may be having problems using them as the wheels are so narrow. Enable this preference and see the nice big plump wheels, perfect for manly fingers! 

•Chronological: When displaying the history of a single exercise in the History tab, you have the option of ordering the workout sets chronologically or most recent first. 

•Display Mode: This pertains to the graphs of your workouts. The normal mode draws a dot for every single set of an exercise that you recorded. These dots can be so close together that can be kind of confusing. To simplify, you have the option of viewing your data on a daily basis.

Nagging is reduced. 
You will still get messages that are *really* important! 

(I'm sick and tired of the program asking me to fill out forms and fields that I don't have time to fool with!)
Nagging is on. \n\nI like being reminded of things that I may have forgotten to do (default).
Can you hear that\? Yeah, I think this program is trying to make some noises (default)!
Shhhhh, we\'re playing the quiet game now. Don\'t make a sound.
Adjust the volume of the sound effects with a slider.
The display will stay on as long as this app is activie.
While using this app, the screen saver will kick in according to your system settings (default).
The Exercise Set History will try to save space when displaying your workout sets.
The Exercise Set History will display all details in a large and easy-to-read style (default).
The oldest (first) workout set will be displayed at the top.
Your most recent workout set will be at the top (default).
Simplify workout graphs into daily clumps.
Graph each and every workout set (default).
When adding a workout set, we want to use those nifty number wheels (default).
I find those number wheels annoying, so they are now gone. Good riddance!
Thin wheels are now displayed. Good for slender fingers and a clean interface (default).
Now displaying fat wheels\u2014good for tired or stumpy fingers.
Set the size of the wheel text (default 12).
Here you adjust the size of the text in the wheels to suit your tastes. Default is 12.
Here is a list of all your exercises. Tap on one to see your progress in that exercise.

You want to see your progress (or lack thereof)\? You're in the right place. 

On this screen you see a graph (also called a chart) of this exercise. 

• The horizontal axis is time, with each individual exercise set presented with its own position (in Daily mode, each day has its own position). 

• The vertical height represents the quantities of the aspects of that exercise. 

• You can pinch to zoom in and scroll left and right by swiping to inspect details of your graph. 

• Modes: All Sets vs. Daily 
   – All Sets displays every single workout set you entered for this exercise. Some may have taken place just a minute or so apart, making them appear to overlap on this graph. Zooming in will eventually reveal these sets as seperate events. 
   – Daily mode avoids the overlapping problem by summing up all the sets in the same day. The way it works is a little complicated and explained in great detail in the options screen.
All sets are the same value\u003a %s
All values are invalid, so there\'s nothing to graph. Sorry. Try filling some of the missing values.
There\'s just one set for the %s exercise, so there is nothing to graph. \n\nBut here is the data for it\u003a
You have only recorded one day for the %s exercise, so there is nothing to graph. \n\nBut here is the data for it (in daily mode)\u003a

This button takes you to a dialog where you can customize how your graphs are displayed for this exercise. Pretty cool, right? \n\nMake sure to long-touch the various items to get detailed explanations of what each does.

Here you customize the display of the graphs for this exercise. 

 • Check or uncheck the buttons to control which aspects are shown in the graph. 

 • The reps-and drop-down button lets you combine the reps with another aspect. For example, instead of simply counting how many bench presses you did at 100 pounds, select reps-and, then select weight, and you will see the number of reps times the weight. Yes, that's ALL the weight you moved in that set total! 
   – Note: this is automatically done for most aspects when in Daily mode. 

• Speaking of that, the Display Mode affects how sets in the same day are handled. The default is all sets, which simply shows every set you recorded. 

If two or more sets are very close together in time (like on the same day), they will appear to overlap unless you zoom in quite a bit. Daily mode solves that problem by combining all the sets of the same day into one graph point. Long-click on the Display Mode button for more details.
Each checkbox displayed here represents an aspect of your workout. \n\nTurn on or off what aspects you want to see in the graph window with these checkboxes. Simple, right?

This part of the graph is a little unusual, so I'll try to break it down for you. 

Sure, it's nice to know how many reps you did. And it's nice to know how much weight you are pushing, too. But wouldn't it be great to know the total weight you moved during that set? Well, I think so. Hence this feature. 

Turn this on, and a graph will show the total weight you moved for each set. Yeah, reps * weight = total. 

But wait, that's not all! You can do other things besides weight! Just tell the program what to multiply the reps by. 

• Select this drop-down button, and a list will pop up. Pick what you want to graph multiplied by reps. 

Now you can walk over to that muscle-head and brag that you lift more per set them him (except that you did 150 reps of ten pounds instead of his two reps of…well I can't count that high, but you get the picture).
I hate to be a pain about this, but you gotta turn on SOMETHING for the grapher to display. \n\nHow else can I show off all that beautiful code?

These buttons give you two options for how to display your workout data. 

All sets (default) graphs a point for every single exercise set you enter. If you do more than one set per day, you may see the graph clump the sets together so closely that you must zoom in a LOT to notice any difference. 

• Daily shows all the results of each day added up. This is kind of complicated. Here goes: 

All the repetions for a day are added together. So if you did one set of ten, another set of five, and a third set of just one, you will see 16 graphed for reps that day. 

The other aspects are similar to reps, but take repetitions into account. 

So for that same exercise sets, if you did fifty pounds for the first set, eighty pounds for the second set, and one hundred pounds for the third set, you moved a grand total weight of 1000 pounds (10 x 50 + 5 x 80 + 1 x 100 = 1000, ✔ ). 

If reps is not present for a particular exercise (like for jogging, which just includes time and distance), then no multiplication is done; the sets are simply added up for the day. So if you jogged for 2 miles in the morning, 1 mile during lunch, and burned off some steam after work by jogging 4 miles (whew!), then the daily distance would be 7 miles. Makes sense if you think about it. 

As if that wasn't complicated enough, levels don't make sense to accumulate. So they are averaged for the day (yeah, a weighted average if reps are present—for you nerds). This means that if you ran on an eliptical trainer at level eight for a while and then ran again at level ten, your daily level would be averaged to a 9. Makes sense, too, but you have to think harder about it. 

And finally, there's the aspect initially called other (you should have given it a more meaningful name when creating the exercise). Since this apect is quite customizable by the user (that's the main point of it), the program can't know how to summarize a day of these sets. So my best guess is to simply display the highest value for the day. 

Sorry about the long help page, but there's a lot to explain here.
A few of the more recent sets\u003a
You have not done any sets of this exercise yet.
Pressing this button shows the recent history of this exercise.

Want control of all that workout data for more than one person? That's what this screen is for! 

Most of the time it's just you and your workout. But sometimes you might want to share your phone with a friend, keep track of another person, or experiment around—that's what this section is for. 

Your workouts are grouped by person: each person (or user) has one group of workout data. The users are listed on this screen. 

• To change who is the currently active user, scroll through the list and tap to make that person active. 

• You can create a new user by typing a name and hitting the add button. 

• Long-tap (press and hold for one second) a user to edit that user's workout data. You'll be able to delete, rename, or clear that user's data on that screen.
Tap to select or long-press for more options.
Enter the name of a new user (usually the name of the) person doing the exercise) and then tap the add button. That\'s all there is to it!

This button allows you to import a data set. \n\nData needs to be in a public directory on your device or accessible as a URL (an internet link). Furthermore, the data needs to be in a tab-delineated format, which is pretty standard for most simple spreadsheets.
The username you typed in (%s) is already taken. Try a different name.
For your sake and the sanity of this program, please do not delete the last set of data!
When you\'re done, you\'re done! \n\nTap here when you have exhausted your admiration of the beauty of this screen and want to admire the beauty of the welcome screen.

Here you have options of what to do with a user\'s set of data. \n\nYou may give the user a new name (rename), delete that user, or clear all of that user\'s exercise data. If I think of something else you can do with it, I\'ll add that option, too.

Hey! Pay ATTENTION! 

You are about to delete an entire user! 

Are you SURE you want to get rid of this person's data for all time?
Yes, this does exactly what you think it does. It permanently removes the selected user and all their data. And yes, there is no going back. \n\nSo be careful!

Did you just get married and want to change your name? Or maybe you just don\'t like your name? Regardless of the reason, this is how you rename your data. \n\nSimply type the new name here and press the change button. That\'s all there is to it.
I can\'t rename this data without a new name! Try typing something, ok?
Yes, this button sends you back to the previous screen without doing anything. Why do I even bother explaining something so obvious? \'Cause I\'m nuts.

Think about this carefully. 

You are about to completely and permanently delete all the data that this device has ever collected for this entire user. 

All the workout sets, all the exercises will go poof as soon as you click 'yes'. 

Are you REALLY SURE you want to delete %s entirely?

This is the tabula rasa (clean slate) for all your exercise data. That means the information of all those workout sets for this user will be erased for good. \n\nThe exercises you created will still be there (whew, at least you don\'t have to do that again!). one-by-one by long-touching them at the main grid.

You are going to delete all the information you entered about your exercise sets (the weights, the reps, when you did them, how hard, graphs, etc.). That info will go poof into the wind. Yep, it won\'t come back. \n\nSo you\'ve been warned. Do you still want to permanently remove all trace of those exercises you sweated hard for?
